579.2: Any person who has a conflict with his fellow, should not permit himself to confidently maintain the justness of his position, because "one does not see his own wrong" (Shabbat 119a). Rather, he should put forth his claims with truth and simplicity before an established Rabbi, asking him to rule whether or not he is obligated to return money to his fellow. And even if his fellow is not bringing him to court, he is still obligated to fulfill his obligation towards heaven by asking a Torah scholar who is an expert decision-maker, as it is written (Mishna Avot Ch.1) "Make for yourself a Rabbi and avoid doubt". And even if his fellow does not know of the theft that was taken from him, one still has to return what was stolen and appease him. [Yalkut Yosef Moadim pg. 78. Chazon Ovadia on High Holidays pg.240]

1.0: It is worthy and good for every G-d fearer to be troubled and worried by the destruction of the Bet Hamikdash and the exile of the Shekhinah, as it says, "Get up and sing in the night, at the beginning of the watches." And just like the Holy One, Blessed be He laments at that time, and says, "Woe to me that I destroyed my house..." like this for everyone who G-d touched his heart to lament in the middle of the night about the destruction, and on the spreading of Israel through the nations, and the exile of the Torah, and the killing of the righteous. And everybody who is able to wake up in the middle of the night, he should do it and say "Tikkun Hasot". And also, if you remain awake until the middle of the night, try not to sleep until you say Tikkun Hasot, to join with the pain of the Shekhinah in exile. However, when you pray and learn Torah you should be happy. And in any case, if you cry during the prayer, you prayer is accepted more.

0.0: We learned in Masechet Avot, Yehuda son of Tema says, (Pirkei Avot 5:20) "Be bold like a leopard, light like an eagle, run like a deer, and strong like a lion to do the will of your Father in Heaven." And they learned from here four rules in serving Hashem "be bold like a leopard" when someone does a Commandment (Mitzvah) they shouldn't be embarrassed from those who mock him. "And light like an eagel" to quickly close his eyes from seeing bad things because the watching of eyes are the start of the sin. "And run like a deer" That the feet should run to do good things. "And strong like a lion" this is a overpowering over the human will. And therefore one should power-up like a lion to stand in the morning to serve Hashem, like you awaken the dawn. No matter what one shouldn't be late to the time of of prayers or the time of saying SHEMA ISRAEL. [The main strengthening  should be in the heart to, to overcome his will to win it, like a powerful man overpowers his hater and wins him and drops him to the earth. This is how one should fight is evil inclination, like a lion, get up from his sleep to server hashem ]. (Yalkut Yosef, Hashkamat HaBoker pg. 57). And never the less, that one who does a mitzvah, he should not be embarrassed from those who make fun of him, and anyway don't quarrel with them and fight the them, in order that he wouldn't get used to the trait of boldness which is very improper. And if his aim is to influence the eyes of the community in the matter of Torah or Mitzvot, and he tried already the way of peace but wasn't successful, then he is allowed to bolden himself to fight with them to defeat their wrong thoughts.
0.3: A person shouldn't think the more sleeping he has is better for one's body, doctors have already agreed that a person shouldn't sleep less than 6 hours and no more than 8. Furthermore, it could be harmful for your health. And they said in the Gemara: When the righteous sleep, it's bad for them and bad for the world. The Torah that they toil in protects the generation, when they're not learning calamity comes to the world. Additionally in the Gemara it says that scholars that toil in Torah during the night, the Torah considered it as if they're involved in the sacrificial services. They also said, in the Jerusalem Talmud someone who is working the Torah in modesty (at night where nobody can see him) he does not forget his learning quickly. And Maimonides wrote: Even though it's a mitzvah to learn night and day, a person learns most of his wisdom at night. Therefore, if someone wants to merit the crown of Torah, he should be careful every single night, not to waste is on sleeping, eating and idle chatter, rather it should be with Torah and words of wisdom.

A person should wake up early enough in the morning so he can prepare himself to pray in cleanliness (bathroom, mikveh, etc), so he shouldn't miss out on praying on the right time. There's a custom in a some Jewish congregations, that the assistant of the congregation goes in the morning and knocks on doors and windows to wake up people for prayers and services of g-d.

2.0: One should be careful to be modest when he dresses or undresses, and one shouldn't say "Behold I am in hidden rooms 'who can see me?' because Hashem's presence fills the entire universe. A person who usually dresses modest should be careful not to reveal [skin] out of respect for Hashem. When one arises he should be very swift to dress himself. A child who understands things should be taught from a young age to dress himself modestly. (Yalkut Yosef, Hashkamat HaBoker pg. 207).

279.2: The entire congregation is required to recite the haftarah quietly together with the one leading the congregation. [Yalkut Yosef, Shabbat A, pg 352].
279.5: On a shabbat when a double-portion is read, the haftara of the second portion is recited, as that is the portion that concludes the [Torah] reading.

280.0: Even though a person listens to the entire Torah reading every Shabbat from the leader of the congregation, he must read it to himself, the verses twice and a translation once. And anyone who completes his [weekly] Torah portion [study] with the congregation [is blessed with] lengthy days and years. And also, one who is engrossed in the study of Torah the entire day, and his Torah study is his profession, may not withdraw from reading the weekly Torah portion with the congregation. He must read the portion, the verses twice and the translation once. And if one is engrossed in Torah to the point that involves the recording of insights and rulings, he is permitted to read on Friday night, the verses twice and the translation once. [Yalkut Yosef, Shabbat Vol.1 pg 354].

161.0: synagogues and houses of learning are called "a minor sanctuary (mikdash)"as it says and I will be for them a minor sanctuary- these are synagogues and houses of learning. And they have holiness.  And so it is important to be very careful in their honor, and to clean them well.  And one should sit in them in fear and awe, and light within them a ner tamid for honor....
